The storage requirements say it needs to be refrigerated and shouldn't be exposed to temperatures above 86 degrees for extended periods. I have no idea what temperature it reached sitting in that enclosed porch, but it's definitely been compromised. Called the specialty pharmacy and they're sending a replacement at no charge, but this is a waste of medication due to a delivery error. They said I should not use the mis-delivered pens since the temperature excursion was so prolonged.

reasoning: Category: Storage/Temperature excursion. Two-day unrefrigerated storage due to delivery failure constitutes temperature excursion.

complaint: My blood sugar was 35. I was unconscious. The paramedics gave me IV glucose. I woke up in the ambulance. It was a severe low.

complaint: My eye doctor has been monitoring my diabetic diabetic eye disease for years now, and it's always been pretty stable. reasoning: Category: Eye disorders (Diabetic retinopathy complications). Temporal association with known risk of retinopathy worsening warrants categorization here.

complaint: This is actually my second report about injection site reactions because they keep happening. Every single time I inject, the area gets red and irritated. It stayed like that for almost 4 days before starting to improve. My pharmacist said some people just have more sensitive skin reactions to the medication. She suggested I try icing the area before injection and rotating my sites more carefully. The medication is helping my diabetes though so I want to keep taking it if possible. Just wish the injection sites wouldn't get so angry every time.

reasoning: Category: Injection-site reactions. Localized cutaneous reaction at administration site without systemic features.

complaint: I use a mail order pharmacy for my Ozempic because it's cheaper than going to the local pharmacy, but this delivery was a disaster. The package was delivered yesterday afternoon while I was at work - it was left on my front porch at around one PM according to the delivery timestamp. I didn't get home until almost seven PM, so it had been sitting out there for about six hours. And yesterday was brutal - we had a heat advisory with temperatures over 95 degrees, and my porch gets direct sun all afternoon. When I picked up the package it felt warm, definitely not cool like refrigerated medication should be. Inside, the gel ice pack that's supposed to keep it cold was completely melted, just warm liquid at that point. And there was one of those temperature indicator strips on the inner packaging, and it clearly showed that the product had been exposed to high temperatures for an extended period. The indicator was red or orange, I forget exactly which, but either way it means the temperature got too high. According to the information sheet, this medication is supposed to stay refrigerated and prolonged heat exposure can make it ineffective or degraded. I called the mail order pharmacy customer service and after being on hold forever, they agreed to send a replacement overnight, but this is a waste of medication and it's concerning that their shipping methods allow this to happen. They need better insulated packaging or refrigerated shipping options, especially for summer deliveries.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Category: Storage/Temperature excursion. Extended high-temperature exposure during shipping exceeds storage specifications and may compromise efficacy.
